Posts.Content: covertanjou wrote: Hello all, I am going in for an excisional biospy on Friday.  My question is that since I do not have a palpable lump (the biopsy is for LCIS/ADH, columnar cell changes, and other changes in breast tissue), how much tissue is removed?  I have a "clip" in my breast that was left there after my stereo biopsy, so does the surgeon go in and just remove tissue around this clip? Also, can the surgeon see if there is cancer during surgery, or is the biopsy always necessary for dx. Thank you to all.  You have all made my emotional rollercoaster bearable as I go through this scary time. “I distrust those people who know so well what God wants them to do because I notice it always coincides with their own desires.” - Susan B. Posts.Content: covertanjou wrote: Hi, I was wondering if anyone here could help answer some questions for me. I am going in for surgery next week (dx LCIS/ADH after stereo biopsy).  Doctor is doing an excisional biopsy.   1. Is sentinel node removal standard during this type of surgery? 2. How bad is the pain? 3. How long before I can start exercising (weights) and doing stuff around the house, driving? 4.  How do I deal with the mounting terror about what they might find?  I am trying to be strong for everyone, so I feel I am keeping all my fears to myself.   5. What are the chances of there being something besides LCIS/ADH and other columnar changes? 6. What is the difference between an excisional biopsy and a lumpectomy?  As always my thanks to all of you.  I would not have been able to go through this without the help of all my sisters on this board. “I distrust those people who know so well what God wants them to do because I notice it always coincides with their own desires.” - Susan B. I am feeling very positive tonight, and I am trying to keep the scary thoughts away.  It is not always easy, but having people like you share their stories and give me encouragement helps me so much. Take care, Mary

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2011 11:05PM - edited Jul 31, 2011 11:07PM by covertanjou What hospital are you at?  If the results are ready, you could and should call another hospital and ask to see a breast surgeon.  The new BS could get the results for you.  Also, do you have a family dr?  Your family doctor can also get the results for you. I had a similar problem 2 years ago. My BS at the Royal Victoria went on holiday, and I called the Jewish General and was seen by a BS the same week. ETA: you can also go to the Ville Marie Clinic.  It is private, and you can have your biopsy done there.  I hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Long wait for biopsy results in Montreal Harvest debsie1

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2009 01:25PM covertanjou wrote: I have ADH/LCIS (discovered on stereo biopsy) and am going in for excisional biopsy in a few weeks.  My understanding is that women with both ADH and LCIS are at very high risk for getting invasive BC.  I can understand your decision.  I will wait for my dx after excision, and then decide what to do..  Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: White spots on MRI covertanjou awb

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2012 10:22AM covertanjou wrote: I often get those after bxs.  I had a huge lump after a bx in Feb.  I called my dr, and after seeing me he said it was a hematoma and to put warm compresses on it or take hot showers and let the water go on the breast.  He told me it would go away after a month, and it did. You may want to check with your dr and try the warm compresses.

Posts.Content: covertanjou wrote: I went for a breast MRI today.  It went well, and apart from trying to stay extremely still and breathing slowly (so not to move the breasts too much) it was okay. I have a few questions for those of you who have gone through MRIs: --did any of you feel the fluid rollng around in your underarm (where the IV was placed?)  Does it mean anything if you do? --I asked to see some of the images, and I saw that my right breast had a lot of shadows and grey matter with some bright spots (1-2).  I also saw 4-6 bright spots in my right underarm. (they seemed oval-shaped).  Does anyone know what this means?  The radiologists wouldn't tell me anything since they said the films needed to be read (understandable). --I have had a headache and pain in my upper back since the MRI is this normal (I realise it could be stress-related). I am a semi-basket case right now and would really appreciate some perspective about what I saw.  Thanks.  “I distrust those people who know so well what God wants them to do because I notice it always coincides with their own desires.” - Susan B. Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2009 10:48PM - edited Nov 10, 2009 10:48PM by covertanjou Hi Willow, First of all, I am sorry you are going through this.  It is always scary when we hear BC.  I had a situation similar to yours when I was 27 and had an 18th month old.  I felt found a large lump, and a doctor who thought it was a saw a fibroadenoma.  I did not have a mammo or ultrasound., but I did have it removed by a breast surgeon by incisional biopsy.  It was a fibroadenoma.  The surgery was a breeze.  I went to the hospital, had a local anesthetic (I was awake), the doctor removed it, and told me immediately he was 99% sure it was NOT cancer.  He was right, it wasn't. Take care and  let us know how you are doing. Mary

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2009 12:51PM covertanjou wrote: mommysta, My dx changed slightly.  The re-read showed ALH as well.  This was not on the original dx.  The first BS basically told me I will see you in 18 months.  Obviously, he is no longer my doctor.  With the new BS the regimen is: see him and get mammo every six months + tamox.    I do have a question for all you ladies.  I had my excisional July 24.  I had healed nicely but now I have quite a bit of pain about 1" BELOW the scar.  The pain is centered around my nipple.  I actually hurts if I touch it.  Could this be the nerve endings connecting, hence the pain, or is it something I should be concerned about?

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2009 07:17PM covertanjou wrote: I have read the same thing (about LCIS being a precursor).  This is especially true if you have pleomorphic cells (which I do).   My surgery is Friday.  I am a basket case: having problems sleeping, etc. I have tried to stay off the boards, not researching, etc., but I find this difficult.  I am torn between wanting to know as much as I can, and wanting to put my head in the sand.  I guess this is pretty normal. Elle, I feel your concerns.  It is so difficult to be positive for your family, and yet afraid of what if. Take care, Mary

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2009 08:17AM covertanjou wrote: HI Mommysta, I had my slides re-read, and the result is LCIS/ADH/ALH.....so the doctor suggested Tamox.  I haven't filled the prescription yet.  I am afraid of the SEs, but getting BC is worse.  BPMs are a possibility for me.  I am going for another mammo in Nov.  For the past 4 years, every time I go for a mammo there is something suspicious.  If this trend continues even with the Tamox, then I will definitely look at BPMs.   It is not an easy decision to make.  When I was first dx with LCIS/ADH I just wanted everything out.  Now.....I am not sure.  For me, it is really tough to have BPMs if I don't have to.  I have learned this summer that I am quite attached to my breasts!! I am sorry if I am rambling....obviously I am unsure about what to do.
Posts.Title: ADH Dx and Tamoxifen mommyalways mommyalways

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2009 03:42PM covertanjou wrote: I am not sure how it works in the US.  I live in Montreal, so I just got a referral to see another doctor at a different hospital, and the new BS requested the slides from the hospital where I had the surgery.  All of my slides were sent to the new BS and hospital.  My original dx was Lobular Neoplasia (LCIS/ADH) and the re-read is Lobular Neoplasia with ADH and ALH. I do think that it is a good idea to get a second opinion when you are dx'd with ADH/ALH/LCIS. mommy..thank you for reassuring me that I am not rambling!
Posts.Title: ADH Dx and Tamoxifen mommyalways mommyalways

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2009 05:02AM covertanjou wrote: CT, From what I have read, if you had an excisional biopsy, the chance of a mis-read is very rare.  This is especially true if you had your surgery at a reputable hospital.  However, it is your right to get a second opinion.
Posts.Title: ADH Dx and Tamoxifen mommyalways mommyalways

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2009 01:19PM covertanjou wrote: I have both ADH & LCIS.  I will have to make a decision about my treatment soon--Tamox, BPMs, etc--it is not an easy decision to make.  I find the BPM radical, but I don't think I can go through constantly finding lumps and getting biopsies.  On the other hand, taking Tamox has some SEs....so, I don't know what to do. You may also find the LCIS forum helpful.  There are many women with LCIS/ALH/ADH who have to deal with these issues.
Posts.Title: ADH Dx and Tamoxifen mommyalways mommyalways

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2009 09:24AM covertanjou wrote: Hi Cathy, It was my decision to postpone my surgery.  Believe me it was not an easy decision because I want this over and done with; however, my family and I scheduled a trip to an all-inclusive resort in Cuba July 5-12, and there was no way I could travel six days after my surgery.  I tried to postpone my trip but couldn't (I hadn't taken cancellation insurance).  I spoke to my doctor, and he said that postponing for 3 weeks was the best decision. He said there was no way I could travel so soon after my surgery.  I am  comfortable with my decision, but I still struggle with it.   I also live in Canada. Where in Canada do you live?  I live in Montreal, and I am really lucky to be afffilated with one of McGill University's hospitals.  I know we have to wait a little longer for our results, but we at least we  don't have to worry about how to pay for our treatment.  I have chatted  with a few women here who have to fight with their insurance companies to get an MRI or an ultrasound.  Overall, my treatment has been very quick.  Went in for a routine mammo at the end of May.  Immediate magnified mammo, ultrasound and biopsy.  Stereo biopsy two weeks later, and (original) surgery 2 1/2 weeks after that.  (I mean no disrespect to my American sisters on this board.) I am thinking of you today and sending lots of hugs.  I am sure everything will go well. The chances of things being okay are on your side.  Don't forget that. Please PM me if you wish.  Please let me know how you are doing.   Mary

Posts.Content: covertanjou wrote: I am going crazy.  Went in for routine mammo and, as usual, something is off (I have fibrocystic breasts).  The mammo shows 2 "masses" + calcifications.  Have an immediate magnified mammo + ultrasound and biopsies on masses.  The two biopsies come back ok, but stereo biopsy is scheduled for calcifications.  The biopsy for that comes back as LCIS/ADH.  Am now going in for excision biopsy.  I am so scared, worried.  I am terrified that when they go in again, they will find something worse.  I need some help and comfort.  I have a supportive husband and family, but I feel I can't speak to them about my fears because I don't want them to worry.  Please tell me how you are dealing with your worries and fears.  “I distrust those people who know so well what God wants them to do because I notice it always coincides with their own desires.” - Susan B.
